title: Tellis Frank
text:
Tellis Joseph Frank Jr. (born April 26, 1965) is an American former professional <a href="basketball">basketball</a> player and former assistant coach for the <a href="Atlanta%20Dream">Atlanta Dream</a> of the <a href="Women%27s%20National%20Basketball%20Association">Women's National Basketball Association</a> (WNBA). At 6'8.5" (2.08 m) and 225 pounds (102 kg) he played as a <a href="power%20forward%20%28basketball%29">power forward</a>.
High school & college career.
Frank is a 1983 graduate of <a href="Lew%20Wallace%20High%20School">Lew Wallace High School</a> (<a href="Gary%2C%20Indiana">Gary, Indiana</a>).
He played college basketball for <a href="Western%20Kentucky%20Hilltoppers%20basketball">Western Kentucky</a> from 1983 to 1987. At Western Kentucky, Frank was a key player in the resurgence of the basketball program. He led the team to its first <a href="Sun%20Belt%20Conference">Sun Belt Conference</a> basketball championship, a top ten national ranking, a 2nd-place finish in the <a href="NIT%20Season%20Tip-Off">pre-season NIT</a>, and back-to-back <a href="1987%20NCAA%20Division%20I%20Men%27s%20Basketball%20Tournament">NCAA tournament</a> appearances.
Professional career.
Frank was selected by the <a href="Golden%20State%20Warriors">Golden State Warriors</a> in the first round (14th overall pick) of the <a href="1987%20NBA%20Draft">1987 NBA Draft</a>.
He played for the Warriors (1987–1989), <a href="Miami%20Heat">Miami Heat</a> (1989–1990) and <a href="Minnesota%20Timberwolves">Minnesota Timberwolves</a> (1991–1992, 1993–1994) during his five-year NBA career, averaging 6.5 <a href="points%20per%20game">points per game</a>. He was briefly signed by <a href="Cleveland%20Cavaliers">Cleveland Cavaliers</a> in 1995, but did not play in any NBA games for the club.
He also played in Italy, for <a href="Juvecaserta%20Basket">Phonola Caserta</a> (1990–1993, won the <a href="Lega%20Basket%20Serie%20A">league</a> in 1991), <a href="S.S.%20Felice%20Scandone">Scandone Avellino</a> (<a href="Serie%20A2%20Basket">Serie A2</a>, 1998–1999), <a href="Pallacanestro%20Don%20Bosco%20Livorno">Basket Livorno</a> (Serie A2, 1999–2000) and <a href="Scafati%20Basket">Longobardi Scafati</a> (Serie A2, 2000–2001). He also played in the Spanish <a href="Liga%20ACB">Liga ACB</a> with three teams in as many years.
